greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of units in the imaginary quadratic field Q(sqrt(-d)), where d > 0 is the n-th squarefree number.
reference: Saban Alaca & Kenneth S. Williams, Introductory Algebraic Number Theory. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press (2004): p. 98, Theorem 5.4.3.
Ivan Niven & Herbert S. Zuckerman, An Introduction to the Theory of Numbers, 4th Ed. New York: John Wiley & Sons (1980): p. 249, Theorem 9.22.
link: M. Hazewinkel, Quadratic field, Encyclopedia of Mathematics, Springer, 2001.
example: Q(sqrt(-1)) = Q(i) has units +/-1, +/-i, so a(1) = 4.
Q(sqrt(-3)) has units +/-1, +/-ω, +/-ω^2, where ω = (1 + sqrt(-3))/2, so a(3) = 6.
Q(sqrt(-d)) has units +/-1 for all other squarefree d > 0, so a(n) = 2 for n = 2 and n > 3.
mathematica: CoefficientList[Series[2 x (2 - x + 2 x^2 - 2 x^3)/(1 - x), {x, 0, 105}], x] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 30 2016 *)
results.author: _Jonathan Sondow_, Jan 29 2014
